context_quality.assessment: REFLECT provided minimal actionable context. Historical learnings were present (DSL iterations, verified code) but no domain-specific guidance about data source reliability, fallback strategies, or known ESPN URL issues from previous 404 failures.
gaps: No warning about ESPN URL fragility despite multiple 404 errors in previous runs
No guidance on alternative data sources for Springbok results
No context about what constitutes 'individual player performance analysis' - leading to incomplete data structure
No prioritization of which coaching analysis dimensions matter most to Rassie

agency_effectiveness.assessment: ACT correctly reused verified code and handled the ESPN 404 gracefully without crashing. However, it showed no agency in seeking alternative data sources or enriching player performance analysis when the primary source failed repeatedly.
what_worked: Graceful error handling - code didn't crash on 404, logged warning appropriately
Correct conditional logic - no coaching tips created when no new game detected
Data preservation - existing game data structure maintained even with 0 games
what_failed: No proactive search for alternative Springbok results sources despite repeated ESPN failures
Player performance analysis remains superficial (empty try_scorers, conversion_scorers fields suggest scraping doesn't capture individual contributions)
No attempt to use LLM to enrich basic score data with performance insights
Cached code reused without considering that ESPN URL has consistently failed

key_issues: Technical pass but business failure - 0 games means no actual coaching value delivered
Player performance analysis structure exists but remains empty/untested
Coaching tips generation logic untested due to no game data
suggestions: Consider implementing alternative data sources or fallback URLs in case the primary ESPN URL returns 404 errors
Add retry logic with exponential backoff for transient network failures
Consider scraping from multiple rugby statistics websites to increase resilience
Add validation to detect when the ESPN URL structure may have changed

strategic_insights: Verification passing with 0 games indicates criteria are too lenient - should fail when no business value delivered
Repeated ESPN 404 errors across multiple runs suggests need for data source diversity strategy, not just retry logic
Player performance analysis is specified in requirements but implementation remains shallow - need clearer definition of what 'how well each individual played' means
Coaching tips generation has never been tested in practice - LLM prompt quality unknown
System optimizes for technical correctness over business value delivery
recommendations_for_next_run: REFLECT should flag ESPN URL as unreliable and prioritize finding alternative sources (SA Rugby official site, RugbyPass, World Rugby)
REFLECT should provide specific guidance on player performance metrics to track: tackles made, meters gained, turnovers won, penalties conceded, minutes played
ACT should demonstrate agency by researching alternative data sources when primary fails, not just logging warnings
VERIFY criteria should require minimum game count or flag runs where 0 games represents business failure
Consider two-phase approach: Phase 1 uses simpler source for basic scores/dates, Phase 2 uses LLM to analyze match reports for player performance insights
Add explicit learning: 'ESPN Scrum URL unstable - prioritize SA Rugby official fixtures orRugbyPass API'
